location.specific_location: Multiple landing grounds (L.G. 21, Gambut West, Msus, El Hassiet, El Nogra)

coordinates.description: Operating from various Western Desert landing grounds following the Allied advance after El Alamein

formation_commander.name: J.H. Wedgewood
formation_commander.notes: Squadron Leader Wedgewood credited with 9 enemy aircraft destroyed during desert campaign; led successful engagement on 21 September 1942

key_personnel.name: Neville F. Duke
key_personnel.notes: Posted back to 92 Squadron in November 1942 after previous service with 112 Squadron; later flight commander February 1943; added 14 victories to his total

key_personnel.name: J.L. Waddy
key_personnel.notes: Final operational posting to 92 Squadron in October 1942; scored last of his 16 victories with the squadron

key_personnel.name: John Morgan
key_personnel.notes: Shot down Bf 109 on 25 October 1942 for his sixth victory during El Alamein operations

key_personnel.name: P.H. 'Hunk' Humphreys
key_personnel.notes: Returned to operations with 92 Squadron in early 1943 after previous service

personnel.personnel_notes: Squadron deployed to Egypt in February 1942 with 11 officers and 317 other ranks, but by 1942q4 likely at standard establishment

primary_aircraft.notes: Tropicalized variant; primary fighter equipment received August 1942
Tropicalized variant with universal wing; mixed with Mk Vb in squadron use

recent_engagements.engagement: Combat patrol vs Bf 109s and Macchi 202s
recent_engagements.description: Eight Spitfires led by CO engaged formation of 50 Bf 109s and Macchi 202s; after 10 minutes Axis aircraft retreated
recent_engagements.outcome: Successful defensive action maintaining formation integrity

recent_engagements.description: Four Spitfires from 92 Squadron attacked two Bf 109s
recent_engagements.outcome: One Bf 109 shot down into sea by Flt Lt John Morgan (6th victory)

recent_engagements.description: Three ME 109s destroyed as Eighth Army broke through Axis lines
recent_engagements.outcome: Enemy aircraft destroyed supporting Allied advance

recent_engagements.description: Ju 88 bomber shot down bringing squadron total to 218.5 victories
recent_engagements.outcome: Squadron continued high victory tally tradition

operations.operational_tempo: High - continuous operations during El Alamein and subsequent Allied advance

Fighter sweeps supporting Allied advance across Western Desert
Defensive counter-air operations against Luftwaffe and Regia Aeronautica
Advanced through multiple landing grounds following Allied offensive (November-December 1942)

bases_used.notes: Initial operations over El Alamein sector

bases_used.location: Western Desert, part of RAF El Amiriya complex
bases_used.notes: Primary operational base during El Alamein period
Advanced landing ground following Allied breakthrough

supply_logistics.ammunition_notes: Continuous combat operations indicate sustained ammunition supply; .303 British for machine guns, 20mm for cannon-armed variants
supply_logistics.water_notes: Squadron operating in Western Desert required water transport; RAF logistics provided potable water at landing grounds

supply_logistics.operational_radius_notes: Spitfire Mk V typical combat radius; operations conducted over Western Desert battlefield and coastal areas

weather_environment.terrain_notes: Operations from temporary landing grounds on desert hardpan; frequent base relocations following Allied advance
weather_environment.seasonal_factors: Autumn/early winter period with improving flying conditions; reduced extreme heat compared to summer months

Dust storms reducing visibility and aircraft serviceability
Limited water resources requiring careful logistics
Harsh conditions on aircraft maintenance requiring frequent servicing
Operating from primitive landing grounds with minimal facilities
Frequent base relocations during Allied advance requiring mobile maintenance capability

historical_significance.importance: High - No. 92 Squadron RAF was one of the most successful RAF fighter squadrons, ultimately claiming 317 victories by war's end (highest in RAF). Squadron's Spitfire operations during El Alamein period contributed to Allied air superiority over Western Desert.
notable_facts: Squadron received Spitfires in August 1942 after initial period flying with 80 Squadron's Hurricanes
Provided continuous air cover during critical Second Battle of El Alamein (October-November 1942)
Successfully engaged superior numbers (8 vs 50 aircraft on 21 September 1942) demonstrating tactical skill
Advanced through seven different bases in three months (November-December 1942) showing operational flexibility
By October 1942, squadron had already achieved 218.5 victories
Squadron known as 'East India Squadron' reflecting its heritage and sponsorship
Notable pilots served during this period including Neville Duke who would become famous test pilot post-war
historical_significance.legacy: 92 Squadron's performance in North Africa exemplified RAF fighter operations during the Western Desert campaign; unit's high victory tally and operational tempo contributed significantly to Allied air superiority that enabled ground force success at El Alamein and subsequent advance

notes: No. 92 Squadron RAF deployed to North Africa in February 1942 and began Spitfire operations in August 1942. During 1942q4, the squadron was heavily engaged in the Second Battle of El Alamein and subsequent Allied advance across Libya. The unit operated tropicalized Spitfire Mk Vb and Vc variants from a series of advancing landing grounds. Squadron demonstrated high operational effectiveness with documented combat successes against Luftwaffe and Regia Aeronautica. Multiple relocations during the quarter reflect the fluid nature of the campaign following Allied breakthrough at El Alamein. Data quality is Tier 2 (68% complete) - good operational and equipment details but lacking precise strength figures and casualty data which would require primary source access.
